scalesUsed.notes: Bb - C - D - Eb - F - G - A - Bb
scalesUsed.application: Primary harmonic foundation and melodic content
Chuck Berry's lead guitar fills and double stops
Additional lead guitar phrasing and blues inflections

mainProgression.description: Classic 12-bar blues progression in Bb major, the foundation of rock and roll

sectionProgressions.progression: Bb - Bb - Bb - Bb - Eb - Eb - Bb - Bb - F - Eb - Bb - F
sectionProgressions.romanNumerals: I - I - I - I - IV - IV - I - I - V - IV - I - V
sectionProgressions.description: Standard 12-bar blues progression with the classic turnaround
Simplified progression emphasizing the primary chords

sectionProgressions.progression: Bb - Bb - Bb - Bb - Eb - Eb - Bb - Bb - F - Eb - Bb - F
sectionProgressions.romanNumerals: I - I - I - I - IV - IV - I - I - V - IV - I - V
sectionProgressions.description: Same 12-bar structure as verse, providing framework for Chuck Berry's lead work

harmonicFunction: Bb (I) - Establishes the tonic center and home chord
Eb (IV) - Provides subdominant movement and harmonic lift
F (V) - Creates dominant tension that resolves back to Bb
12-bar structure creates cyclical harmonic motion typical of blues and early rock

techniques.name: Chuck Berry Double Stops
techniques.description: Chuck Berry's signature technique using two-note harmonies played simultaneously on adjacent strings. This creates the distinctive 'duckwalk' sound that defined early rock and roll guitar.

details.scalePattern: Bb major pentatonic - intervals of 3rds and 6ths
details.musicalFunction: Creates harmony while maintaining single-note feel
notes: Practice slowly with clean tone first
Focus on clean fretting to avoid muted notes
Use alternate picking for clarity
Keep fingers curved to avoid touching other strings
tips: Keep fingers curved for clean notes
Start at slower tempo and build speed
Focus on the 'snap' of each double stop

techniques.name: Johnny B. Goode Main Riff
techniques.description: The iconic opening and recurring riff pattern that combines single notes with Chuck Berry's signature style. This riff became one of the most recognizable in rock history.

details.rhythmPattern: Syncopated eighth notes with open string accents
details.musicalFunction: Establishes key center and rhythmic drive
practiceSteps: Play slowly with metronome at 100 BPM
Focus on clean single notes first
Build up to 145 BPM performance tempo
notes: Use thumb and index finger picking or alternate picking
Emphasize beat 1 and 3 for strong rhythm foundation
Keep bass notes ringing for full sound
The open 6th string provides rhythmic punctuation

techniques.name: Alternating Bass Lines
techniques.description: Walking bass patterns on the lower strings that provide the driving rhythm foundation characteristic of Chuck Berry's style.

notes: Use thumb and index finger picking
Emphasize beat 1 and 3 for strong rhythm
Keep bass notes ringing for full sound

techniques.name: Lead Guitar Fills
techniques.description: Single-note runs and fills played between vocal phrases, using pentatonic scales and blues-based phrasing.

notes: Based on Bb major pentatonic scale
Use bend and release techniques
Focus on rhythmic placement between vocals

sections.name: Intro
sections.description: The iconic opening riff that immediately establishes the Chuck Berry sound with double stops and driving rhythm. This riff became the template for countless rock and roll songs.

riffAnalysis.technique: Alternating single notes with double stops
riffAnalysis.musicalFunction: Establishes key, tempo, and Chuck Berry style

notes: Start with clean attack on the 3rd fret
Emphasize the syncopated rhythm - slightly ahead of the beat
Build energy for the vocal entry
The open 6th string provides rhythmic punctuation

sections.name: Verse 1
sections.description: Establishes the main chord progression with rhythm guitar supporting the vocal melody.
sections.progression: I - IV - I - V - IV - I
notes: Use muted strumming technique
Keep steady eighth-note feel
Leave space for vocal phrasing

sections.name: Guitar Solo
sections.description: Chuck Berry's signature lead guitar work featuring double stops, bends, and pentatonic runs. This solo established the template for rock guitar solos.

riffAnalysis.technique: Double stops, single note runs, string bending
riffAnalysis.scale: Bb major pentatonic with blues inflections

keyTechniques: Call and response with rhythm section
notes: Focus on rhythmic placement - play slightly ahead of beat
Use alternate picking for clarity and attack
Build intensity throughout the solo
Bend the 8th fret on 3rd string for classic Chuck Berry sound

sections.name: Verse 2
sections.description: Returns to the main progression with added energy and guitar embellishments.
sections.progression: I - IV - I - V - IV - I

sections.name: Outro
sections.description: Drives to the conclusion with repeated riff patterns and final chord resolution.

effects.other: Minimal effects - focus on clean Chuck Berry tone

beginner.title: Getting Started with Rock and Roll
beginner.goals: Play basic chord progression and understand song structure

intermediate.title: Building Chuck Berry Style
intermediate.goals: Play rhythm parts confidently and begin double stop work

advanced.title: Mastering the Lead Work
advanced.goals: Master all guitar parts and perform with authentic Chuck Berry style

sameArtist.title: Roll Over Beethoven
sameArtist.similarity: Similar Chuck Berry double stops and rock and roll style

sameArtist.title: Memphis Tennessee
sameArtist.similarity: Same guitar techniques and musical approach

similarTechniques.title: Thunderstruck
similarTechniques.similarity: Iconic riffs and lead guitar techniques

similarTechniques.title: Good Golly Miss Molly
similarTechniques.similarity: Early rock and roll energy and chord progressions

commonMistakes: Rushing the tempo during the intro riff
Muddy double stops from poor fretting technique
Playing too loudly and losing the clean Chuck Berry tone
practiceRoutine: Start with chord progression at slow tempo (100 BPM)
Practice double stops separately before combining with rhythm
Work on clean transitions between sections
metronomeWork: Work on playing slightly ahead of beat for rock feel
